area_description_data.5: Main thoroughfares: Castleton Ave., Henderson Ave. Protected on north and east by Sailors Snug Harbor, a well maintained home for retired seamen. Inhabitants of area are largely N.Y.C. commuters. Many have bought here beyond their means with homes mortgaged for 90% of their selling price. Despite this fact there have been very few foreclosures up to the present. Probably the highest loan possible to obtain today in this area would be about $7000. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Are only nominally different from what they were in 1938-39 ($8500 to $10,000.) Offering are infrequent inasmuch as this section is well held by a stable class of dwellers and has consistently been regarded as one of the prime spots on Staten Island. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): Rentals have always been in excellent demand here, and available properties are at a premium. There is not a vacant house in this area today. Despite this exceptional demand, prices have not advanced which is entirely consistent with rental experience elsewhere in the borough. Construction in this area is entirely single family, and the few that are rented bring from $75 to $90 a month. General Comments: This is probably the best balanced, most uniform and typically "A" area on Staten Island. It is not handicapped by the presence of large homes of the estate class as are some of the hill sections in the saem grade. It is, therefore, better lending territory, and in fact institutions compete for loans here. Surroundings and layout are good and there are no adverse influences present. One new home is under construction, in the southeastern portion but aside from this there has been no new construction during the past year, and the area may be said to be leveling off.
area_description_data.1a: Downward slope from south to north. Many large trees.
area_description_data.1b: Uniformity of good structural types. Good transportation-5 cent fare. Zoned residential 100%. Near Park. Near schools. Stores 1/4 mile distant. Restrictions as to size of lot and cost of structure.

area_description_data.5: Principal thoroughfare: Victory Blvd. This is a very exceptional area, and does not follow the general rule of values and rents due to its exceptional advantages for those able to live here. Here are a few very large and expensive estates. Tax valuations were established before the Staten Island land boom of 1923-26 and are accordingly low. A superb location as to scenic advantages. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Recent erection of a large new apartment building on the south side of Victory Boulevard, facing Silver Lake Reservoir has had the effect of stiffening prices somewhat in the immediate vicinity as several old homes stand on potential sites for apartment construction. These sites are all on Victory Blvd., the north boundary of the area, facing Silver Lake Park, Southeast of this boundary the terrain rises sharply, and the interior of the area is built up with large expensive homes. Prices on these have declined somewhat, although the decline is nominal and not supported by any sales. Institutions made few loans in here and have taken very few properties through foreclosure. No demand and no activity. About the minimum price, even in today's market, would be $20,000. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): About $20 a room in the new 65 apartment building on Victory Boulevard facing the Park. This building is nearly filled. Other available rentals are all large single houses which bring from $75 to $100 a month. There are few vacancies in this area which is noteworthy for splendid scenic advantages and convenience to trans-bay transportation. General Comments: New apartment building above mentioned is only new construction. Owners are understood to contemplate further construction of this character and the area is admirably suited therefore. Land valuations here are somewhat lower than elsewhere, which is a further circumstance favoring multi-family construction.

area_description_data.1b: Excellent scenic advantage. Adjacent to park on northwest. Near business area. Near N.Y. ferry. 5 cent fare on bus. Convenient to schools, churches, Low tax valuation. Notre Dame College- Wagner College.

area_description_data.5: Principal thoroughfares: Ocean Terrace, Todt Hill Rd., Clove Rd. A steep bluff separates this area from the yellow and red areas on the east. Establishment of public transportation system opposed by property owners in this "exclusive" neighborhood. Area undeveloped in center but likely to develop along in conformity with present well established pattern. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): This area has seen very little change during the past year. There is little or no demand for property here, and sales have been few. Values have decreased nominally, probably as much as 5%. Improvements are nearly all large single houses, generally in good condition, and with few exceptions modern. One sale within the past year was made by HOLC for $9,500. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): Comparatively few rental properties in the area. Prices however, are pretty well established at from $80 to $100 a month, with only a few outstanding exceptions renting for more. The Staten Island Savings Bank has one house in here which cost $35,000 and is currently offered for $20,000, now rented for $125 a month. General Comments: Many for sale signs of vacant land throughout. A plot approximately 100x100, well located, brings from $2,500 to $5,000. One large new dwelling in the "estate" class has been built this year. The exclusive Richmond County Club commands a magnificent view of lower N.Y. Bay from the south part of this area. Finest present day estate (Flagg) adjoins the club property on the west. HOLC has about three properties in the area at present. Institutions hold little if anything here. Development is slow although some road improvements were noted.
area_description_data.6: Todt Hill (Emmerson Hill) Staten Island  Ample 3
area_description_data.1a: High and rolling with downward slope from center of area in all directions. Steep slope downward at northeast part of area.
area_description_data.1b: Scenic advantages. Country Club and gold courses adjacent. Private school in area. Fine trees. Highly restricted as to size of lot and cost of structures. (Minimum approximately $12,000).

area_description_data.5: No principal highways. Probably the best area in Staten Island, due to location, homogeneity, and high type of structures. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): This area is built up principally of fairly high priced homes, modern and of excellent uniformity. Here has been very little sales activity in existing houses although two or three new ones have been built and sold by contractors. Prices on other than new houses are nominally lower than in 1938-39, having declined so that the present range is about $11,000 to $11,750. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): This is not a rental area; practically all dwellings here are owner occupied. General Comments: This is one of the best of the "A" areas from a point of uniformity and the absence of large estates. It is well protected from encroachment, being surrounded by "B" areas and the park. There were recently built two new five room 1 1/2 story brick and stone veneer, six room cottages. These have built-in garages and are offered for sale at about $8000 or a little better. The contractor has been instrumental in developing a considerable part of this area and still has a number of building sites here for sale. There appears a slight but continuing demand for houses of this type and sales are made only with substantial down payments. In general, the area appears to be levelling off somewhat and the future trend might be stated as static.
area_description_data.1b: Bordering park and golf course. Scenic advantages. 5 cent bus fare. Near churches and schools. Zoned 100% residential. Restricted as to cost and size of lot and cost of structure.

area_description_data.5: Principal highway: Bay St. A small area developed by one of the leading real estate firms of Staten Island. "Exclusive". Fenced in on all sides. Bay front along the "Narrows" channel to N.Y. harbor. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): About 5% lower than 1938-39. At that time there was no sales in this small and somewhat exclusive area excepting a few new ones built for owners. About a year ago the Corporation sold one in here for $8000, which is regarded rather low to be a typical transaction. The predominating house in this area is of the $10,000 class, with better values near the waterfront and the cheaper houses nearer Bay Street. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): Very few rented in here and prices have not changed since 1938-39 when $90 to $100 was customary. This is essentially a tight little community of home owners of the better class for Staten Island. General Comments: With expansion of military operations in nearby Ft. Wadsworth this is a logical spot for a possible overflow of officers' families not able to secure quarters on the Reservation. The area is too small to be of great importance as there were few foreclosures here and not much property is held by institutions and none by HOLC. It is fenced in on all sides. One drawback consists in the unattractive approach along Bay Street, and also in the fact that poorer neighborhoods with low grade foreign population encircle it excepting for the waterfront and the Military Reservation to the south. Roadways are narrow and there are few sidewalks. Not in the path of future development and may be expected barely to hold its place for the next few years. Two new single family dwellings are now under construction here for owners. area_description_data.5: No principal highways. This area is separated from the adjacent red area on the north and east by a very steep drop in the land. Some streets shown on map leading from blue to red area have not been cut. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Only a nominal decline since 1938. Impossible to trace any actual sales here as the area has been pretty close to static for the past two years. Demand is very slow and a static condition may be predicted, due to topographical condition making construction expensive and difficult. Dwellers here have generally been a good stable class and foreclosures were comparatively few. hence no institutional offerings. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): This was never much of a rental area, single family structures being about 90% owner occupied. Apartments and two-family dwellings constituted only 0% of the structures. Prices have remained firm here and vacancy is not exceeding 5% of rental units. Singles command from $75 to $90; units in multiples from $50 to $65. General comments: Assessed valuations here are proportionally lower than almost any place on Staten Island, being about 60% of market value. This is because of the fact that valuations were established here, on land, prior to the land boom in the early twenties. The area is somewhat handicapped by proximity to very much lower class neighborhoods on the east, and further because of abnormally steep slopes, making access difficult in slippery weather. No new construction here, and the trend has not changed since 1938 when it was reported "slowly downward".
area_description_data.1a: On crest of hill, with steep downward slope in all directions, particularly to north and east.
area_description_data.1b: Near ferry, stores and business center. 5 cent bus fare. Churches and schools conveniently near.
area_description_data.1c: Steep grades make access difficult in winter. Building is expensive due to topographical conditions.

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Forest Ave. This area has progressed slowly even during the depression period. Has uniformly good construction, land practically level and favorable for building operation. Sewer and other public improvements present. Room for expansion. Future prosepects favorable, good road connections to all parts, bridges, ferries, etc. Zoning residential with exception of 100' depth from Forest Ave. Sale Prices (Dec.1940): Down about 5% from 1938 levels. Competition of new and cheaper homes, together with price cutting by institutions which had acquired property here accountable for reductions. This area was the scene of a speculative development resulting in some second mortgage transactions which turned out badly in some instances. An active development now going on here which is not calculated to help the market on older homes in the area. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): No perceptible change from 1938-9 levels. Offerings are few and these are readily absorbed at $50 to $65. HOLC has 7 houses in here; all rented. Trend is firm and the area will continue to be good rental territory. General Comments: Impossible to obtain data on comparative sales here. HOLC has sold only one and institutional sales have been very few within the past year. One of the most active developments on Staten Island during the past two years is in the area. About 50 small brick and frame bungalows have been built here during that period, ranging in price up to $6500. The E.J. McCormick Co. has recently completed 20 brick veneer bungalows which are offered with FHA financing, 10% down. A representative of that concern advised that about 80 more are contemplated and land is now being cleared in preparation. In addition to this group, 21 more are to be built by the A.J. Behrens Co. along College Ave. south of Crystal. These also are offered with FHA financing at prices in the $6000 class. However, later development appears slightly inferior to the types which originally went in here and the area may be expected to level off in the near future with completion of the above housing. Demand is said to be somewhat disappointing to the McCormick concern although this has not altered heir plans for the 80 houses mentioned above. Sales have been to a salaried class: firemen, policemen and salesmen traveling for large corporations. So far, none have 'come back'. While the development is not far distant from the shipyards of the north shore, it is worth comment that not an inquirt has been received from that source to date. Desirability decreases somewhat approaching the south boundary, Warchogue Road, which section is somewhat low. The area is further penalized by inadequate transportation and by being entirely surrounded by lower grade neighborhoods.

Some lots were sold at cheap prices and cheap construction may result.

area_description_data.5: Principal highway: Hylan Blvd. Nearly all buildings in this area erected under 10 year tax free provision under which buildings begun by the end of 1922 were granted 10 years freedom from taxation by the city.

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: New Dorp Lane, Hylan Blvde. Most two-family houses in this area, though legally so classified, are actually 4 to 8 family structures, with one foundation and a single roof over the entire structures, with one foundation and a single roof over the entire sturcture. Also a single heating plant. the new high school has furnished a stimulus to activity in this area.
area_description_data.1b: Good transportation: R.R. express service from New Dorp and Grant City to N.Y. ferry. Churhces, schools, stores in the area. High school in adjacent area. Good shade trees.
area_description_data.1c: Temporary roads in few instances. Part of area built up with old type dwellings. 10 cent fare zone.

area_description_data.5: Principal highway: Westervelt Ave. Construction expensive due to steep slopes. Tax valuation on land very high- justified for apartment house purposes but too high for successful development of small dwellings. Northeast section of this area is of higher value than the westerly portion. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Only nominally lower than 1938-39 because this was an old area and prices had been hammered down pretty well by offerings of foreclosed property soon after the market crash of 1929. However most of these have been cleared out, and while prices haven't recovered to any extent, there are pretty steady due to proximity to the New York ferry, the best shopping center of Staten Island and to good amusement facilities. Administration offices of the Borough are located here also. Today's prices on singles range generally from $4500 to $9000; two family structures are in little demand and prices would be $6000 to $6500. Not much activity. Trend slowly downward because of age. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): Convenience of location with respect to New York ferries makes this a good rental district for the commuter with moderate income. Rental demand has always been good here and today there are a dearth of available units. Singles bring from $50 to $80, depending on condition and location; units in two family dwelling; $45 to $60; and apartments in modern buildings rent from $70 to $125. General Comments: Best values are along Ft. Hill Circle, the highest point in the area. There are many old houses in this neighborhood for which there is no present demand except at sacrifice prices. Trend is toward apartments. Land is over valued for tax purposes which is another influence away from single family and toward multi-family construction. This is an "island" in the middle of a fourth grade area. No new construction is to be seen here and some additional pressure will have to come from the rental market to afford stimulus for apartment house construction which is about the only thing the area is suited for.
area_description_data.1a: Hilly with steep down grade to north and east.
area_description_data.1b: Near ferry and administrative center- walking distance. High school. Churches and shopping center in area. Good scenic feature. Highly restricted on Fort Hill Circle at very top of area.
area_description_data.1c: Surrounded by "red area". Many old large houses- Many apartments. Steep slopes- icy in winter and difficult of access.
area_description_data.2a: Business men, few executives on Ft. Hill Circle

area_description_data.5: Principal highway: Richmond Rd. Wagner college adjacent to area and affects rents somewhat due to demand for cheap quarters by students and faculty.  Some Italian concentration around southeastern part of area.  Nearly all good property in this area is "owner occupied". (/n) Sales Price Dec 1940: Possibly 5% lower than 1938-39, although there have been very few sales to support any statement of prices, which must be considered as nominal only.  Demand is poor, and has been, for a long while in this area.  Singles are arbitrarily ranged from $4000 to $5500; few offerings and no takers (/n) Rental prices Dec. 1940: $35 to $45 with fairly good demand and few vacancies amont the 5 to 7 room singles comprising the improvements within the area. (/n) General comments: The area is set apart from the fourth grade sections to the east by a principal thoroughfare, Richmond Road.  The western part of the area terminates in steep slopes against the grounds of two private educational institutions.  Adjacent "red" areas are largely populated by Italians of low earning capacity.  A few of these have come into "C10", principally along the lower slopes to the east.  Infiltration has been slow but will likely continue.  Of little importance to lending institutions, which generally restricted their operations in here, the area has seen little activity and HOLC holdings are at a minimum.
area_description_data.1a: A steep hillside sloping downward to the southeast.
area_description_data.1b: 5 cent fare zone.  A fair degree of privacy.  Churches, stores, and schools near.  Wagner College adjacent.
area_description_data.1c: Typographical difficulties to construction and access.  Present roads are temporary.  Assessments inevitable.  Some properties have no sewer.
area_description_data.2a: Small business men, WPA workers, some clerks

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Bay St., Hylan Blvd., Fingerboard Rd. In this area are a few very cheap poorly constructed single houses, relatively much less desirable than the worst of the 2-family units. Supplemental Information: Sales Prices (Dec.1940): For large old singles (8 to 12 rooms, 40 to 75 years old) about 10% lower than in 1939, with very little demand as it has been experienced that these cannot be remodeled at a profit. Two family structures meet with a better reception here than in some parts of the County less thickly populated with Italian families. Nevertheless, there have been no sales traceable at anywhere near the 1938-39 top figure of $12,000 and this may now be regarded as nominal only. About $8500 would be an average high price for almost anything in the area today. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): About the same as in 1938-39. Very light vacancy here, as elsewhere on Staten Island. Singles in tenantable condition bring from $35 to $50; apartments in 2 family buildings are generally $35 to $45, with very few higher. Conditions have leveled off in the rental market and no immediate change forecast. General Comments: Small cheap one story stores along Bay Street in this vicinity. The neighborhood appears to be going strongly Italian with the almost inevitable down hill trend which usually accompanies influx of this racial group. It may benefit slightly from the anticipated increase in military activity at Ft. Wadsworth but this is rather problematical, and any benefits would likely be indirect inasmuch as the area contains few houses suited for official tenancy. Trend expected to remain somewhat downward. No new construction here during the past year. The Corporation owns a total of 7 houses in the area and has sold 5 in 1940. Institutional holdings are very few. Best values are along Belair Road near the U.S. Quarantine Station. West of Bay Street, the best values are found in the south part of the area. Typical Sales: |Address|Type|Price & Terms|Remarks| (\n) |80 Fingerboard Road| 6 room, frame, single; no garage; 25 foot frontage.| $3800-10% down with lease and option; 5% interest; 5 year least; 1% amortization.| Sold by Staten Is. Savings Bank in good condition; no reconditioning.|
area_description_data.1b: 5 cent fare to N.Y. ferry. Several bus lines and railroad transportation (railroad fare to ferry 8 cents). Good view from higher portion (all southwest of Tompkins Ave.) Schools, churches, stores.
area_description_data.1c: Influx of Italians. Railroad traverses area.

area_description_data.5: This was once a very fine high priced section. Some very old properties are still standing 50-75 years old. There have been many foreclosures in this area. Principal highways: Hylan Blvd., Fingerboard Rd. Supplemental Information: Sales Price (Dec.1940): For singles about $3500 to $7000, with very few sales at the second figure. No demand for two family houses except at sacrifice prices. Prices nominally $6000 to $7000 with few supporting sales. Trend slowly downward. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): No perceptible change. Singles still renting for $30 to $50, with few at the second figure. Units in two-flats are about the price with heat. Trend appears steady here as elsewhere on Staten Island due to shortage of rentable property. General Comments: The above could hardly be called "typical" but sales have been few in here despite the fact that banks took back a considerable number through foreclosure. HOLC has only two in here today, and sold only one last year. The neighborhood is strongly Italian and this trend is expected to continue because of the close proximity of the Italian section, 'D-5". The neighborhood may benefit indirectly through increased activity at Ft. Wadsworth where arrangements are under way to take care of a considerable increase in complement of officers and men. This, however, is not expected to alter the course of an unmistakable downward trend. Typical Sales: |Address|Type| Price & Terms| Remarks| (\n) |336 Garfield Street| Frame single, without garage.| $3200-$200 down; contract sale; interest 5%.| Sold by individual. No further data available, except that sales prices approximated the amount of the mortgage in each sale| (\n) |70 "C" Avenue| Frame single, without garage.| Same as above|
area_description_data.1b: Tree shaded streets- good view- mostly good substantial construction. Schools in area. Stores on McClean and on Ocean Ave. Church in area.
area_description_data.1c: Continuous influx of Italians has changed racial picture. Adjacent to Ft. Wadsworth. Three orphanages in area. Threat of further Italian infiltration because of proximity to D-5. Railroad traverses area.

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Fingerboard Rd., Clove Rd. Built up by same developer who built B-8, but is composed of smaller cheap houses on smaller lots. Supplemental Information: Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Price on singles which comprise 100% of the improvements in this small area, have not changed from 1938-39 levels which were $4500 to $6000. Very little activity and the trend appears reasonably stable. The area is well built up and there is practically no room for further development. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): About the same as 1939: $45 to $50 for singles. (Nothing else available in here.) The area is principally occupied by a fairly good class of home owners and very little is offered for rent, and that little is immediately occupied. General Comments: This area is more influenced by the adjacent B-8 area than by the lower grade property across the tracks to the northwest. The same developers built up by both sections, principal difference being that the "C" portion of "Grassmere" was comprised of smaller lots and houses. Improvements in here are principally frame bungalows and cottages, pretty well maintained and apparently occupied by a better than average type of dweller, considering that this is a 3rd grade area. Typical Sales: |Address| Type| Price & Terms| Remarks| (\n) |15 Lake View Ter.| 6 room stone bungalow with garage. | $6500-$1000 down; Deed and Mortgage at 5 1/2%.| Sold by Westerleigh S&L. No reconditioning.|

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Hylan Blvd.  Section shows no sign of resumption of activity.  Rent increase only due to general shortage of rentable properties on Staten Island; Sales Price (Dec. 1940): Only nominal changes here.  This small and sparsely developed area has been just about completely stagnant, with no demand and no activity excepting for a single new house erected in the east end.  Prices from $2000 to $6500, indicative of the rather wide range of types and condition.  Two or three for sale signs but no sales reported;  Rental prices: about the same as 1938-39 due to high occupancy nearly all over the Island excepting for purely seasonal cottages and shacks.  Singles, with which the area is improved about 50% are renting when available at $35 to $50.  Demand is fairly good despite only mediocre conveniences and transportation;  General comments: Of very little importance since institutions and HOLC have scarcely anything here.  Some benefits may accrue with the development of the Marine Park.  Only one new single house has been built here in the past year or so.  Plenty of lots are available but due to low lying land damp cellars are a frequent complaint and the area is not expected to see much construction; Typical sales: Address, type, price & term, remarks (/n) 60 Falcon Ave, Frame single; garage; hot water heat; 2 baths; good condition; 75 x 100 lot., $4250-$800 down; mortgage; 5% interest, Sold by Richmond Company Federal S&L.
area_description_data.1b: Easy for building operations - land is flat.
area_description_data.1c: Only fair transportation by bus - 15 cent fare.  Railroad station 1/2 mile distant.  Stores 1/2 mile - cheap beach area to southeast.  Salt meadows to south.  Extreme high tides sometimes flooding large part of adjoining area.  Water seepage in cellars.
area_description_data.3q: Slight, due to lack of accomodations

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Richmond Rd., Hylan Ave. *In eastern extremity only, mortgage funds available in limited amounts; Sales Price (dec. 1940): About 5% lower than in 1938-39.  (singles quoted at $2000 to $5250: two family structures $4500 to $7500 with few moving at any price.)  No demand in here.  Institutions not involved to any great extent, and HOLC holdings at a minimum.  The area suffers from two influences: a 4th grade area on the north and a cemetery blocking further develoment on the west.  Distinctly rural in appearance, and little improvement likely here for a long time to come; Rental prices: About $35 to $45 for singles - slightly lower for the more expensive ones than quoted in 1939.  Units in two family dwellings, of which there are only a few available, rent from $30 to $40 depending on condition and location; General comments: Of little significance to lending institutions, which generally have shied off this territory.  HOLC has next to nothing in here, and has sold nothing recently.  Poorly surfaced streets and sewers lacking in part of the area.  Trend at best static.  No developments of importance along the south shore calculated to affect this area.
area_description_data.1a: Level and slightly rolling in western portion.
area_description_data.1b: Stores, schools, churches in village of Richmond.  Golf course near.  Bus transportation along Hylan and Richmond.

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Amboy Rd., Gifford's Lane.  The small percentage of negroes in the area has been there for many years but has not increased.  This is the most active town on the South Shore; Sales Price (Dec 1940): About 5% below 1938-39.  The area is entirely devoted to single family construction, currently priced from $4800 to $6000.  A few houses in the area would sell for less than the predominant range, due to colored occupancy.  Demand is lacking and there have been few sales during the past year.  The community is distinctively rural in character, with nothing to attract the outside buyer; Rental prices: No change from 1938-39 levels due to good demand fostered by high occupancy.  Singles here rent from $35 to $50 a month, usually nearer the lower figure.  Trend appears level and any defense activity such as shipyard or drydock construction, which has been mentioned as a possibility, would cause favorable reaction in this as well as other south shore areas. (Proposed drydock mentioned in connection with Prince's Bay section.); General Comments: Area is unimportant from mortgage lending and property management point of view in as much as there is very little foreclosed property held by Institutions or by HOLC in here.  The area appears stagnant and a spurt probably would result only from some important economic influence such as drydock or allied defense activity on the south shore - a contingency which even so optimistic a body as the Chamber of Commerce is hesitant to predict; Address, Type, Price & Terms, Remarks; 69 Gibson Avenue, 2 story 6 room frame house with hot air heat, $4000 - no down payment and interest at 5% contract of sale, sold by Richmond county Federal after painting and decorating.

area_description_data.5: Principal highway: Victory Blvd. Today's asking sales prices are a result only of the general stiffening of rents. Possibility of encroachment here of lower grade population from adjacent "red" area. Sales Prices(Dec.1940): Only nominally lower than in 1938-39. This is an old neighborhood and due to the strong predominance of the two family type, has seen little activity during the past few years. Institutions never favored the area as lending territory and were accordingly conservative in their commitments. Prices today for two family structures run generally $7000 to $8000 with few sales to support these figures. Single family dwellings are not much in demand and prices are arbitrary at $8000 to $9500. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): About the same as 1938-39: $50 to $60 for units in two family structures: $60 to $70 for single family dwellings. The neighborhood is strongly Hebrew and rental demand is exceptionally good. General Comments: Not much in favor of this area other than convenient transportation and proximity to ferry. No improvement envisioned here and the trend appears to be continued downward slowly. area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Hylan Blvd.  Some development foreseen here if Staten Island Marine Park is developed northeast of area; Sales Price (Dec. 1940): Singles generally range from $4000 to $6500, which is somewhat lower than the more expensive houses were quoted in 1938-39.  Reduction is due to lack of demand and to price cutting in the higher priced units by institutions which held a substantial volume of foreclosed property in here.  Trend is difficult to predict as the future of this area would be greatly enhanced if the proposed drydock site at Prince's Bay should be approved by the Navy.  This matter is now up for decision in Washington; Rental prices: From $30 to $50 for single family houses, depending on condition and location.  No signs of weakening in rents, which is in line with present high occupancy and demand.  Trend is at worst static.  Very few rented at $50; General comments: The village of Great Kills appears to be losing out in competition with its neighbor New Dorp, despite the fact that the former is the location of the only bank between Stapleton and Tottenville.  The motion picture theatre in Great Kills failed recently and other indications point to a somewhat stagnant condition locally.  (Compared to New Dorp).  The Staten Island Savings Bank had an appreciable number of foreclosures in this area but has cleaned out the bulk of its holdings during the past two years.  HOLC has about 8 here now, sold 3 during 1940; Address, Type, Price & Terms, Remarks (/n) 4018 Hylan Avenue; 6 room 2 story frame single, steam heat, painted and redecorated but not otherwise reconditioned; $4000, no downpayment, 5% interest on contract of sale; sold by Richmond County Federal, book value was $3900.
area_description_data.1b: Topographically favorable for building - grade school, churches, stores in area
area_description_data.1c: Railroad station 1 mile distant - bus line to ferry near.  15 cent fare - 40 min to ferry.  Much ground water - wet collars, 70% sewers.

area_description_data.5: Prinicipal highways: Amboy Road, Hylan Blvd.  Houses well maintained.  Owners largely Scandinavian mechanics.  Not many foreclosures here; Sales Price (dec. 1940): About $4000 to $8000 at present, with very few sales at the higher figure, which may be termed arbitrary in the light of today's activity in here.  Areais entirely single family construction; somewhat handicapped by poorly surfaced roads in many parts, lack of sewers in others.  Trend no better than static and it would require drastic defense sctivities along the south shore to start this neighborhood moving; Rental prices: About $30 to $40 for singles.  (Practically none fo those in the $8000 class are rented.)  Demand is fairly good, but rental properties are few and no vacancy was noted in a drive through the area; General comments: A small and isolated portion of this area lies along Hylan Boulevard.  North of this, toward Amboy Road is a tract laid out with streets, most of which are in deplorable condition, some narrow sidewalks, overgrown with weeds and small trees in places, which nevertheless offers possibilities of ultimate development.  The land is splendidly situated; high, overlooking Raritan Bay, and there are many good shade trees, oaks and maples.  This section would be a "natural" for a good developer in the event of the Prince's Bay drydock site being approved.  There are a few small cheap cottages built in here, two of them unsold.  Prices are in the neighborhood of $2500, with payments of $20.90 a month for 15 years under FHA plan.  Apparently no restrictions.  The Hylan Avenue boundary has two or three buildings used for tavern purposes, one of them deserted and completely vandalized. (/n) Address; Type: Price & Terms: Remarks (/n) 141 Wilson Avenue; Single family frame; $4000- 10% down, lease and option, interest, amort. monthly at 1%; Sold by Westerleigh S&L at a net loss of $970.  No reconditioning.

area_description_data.5: Principal highways: Amboy Rd., Annadale Rd. *In 1929 all properties in south section were occupied by owners.  After foreclosure some rented for about $18 a month in 1934 - $25 in 1938.  Area blighted by 20% Sears Roobuck houses; Sales Prices (Dec. 1940): Predominating level today would be somewhere between $4000 and $7500, for single houses which comprise all improvements.  This represents a decrease of $1000 approximately at the upper end of the range.  There is very little demand in here for any sort of housing, least of all for the more expensive ones.  Some improvement foreseen due to a new dual highway which passes through the area from northeast to southwest.  This highway affords more direct connection with the north end of the island, via Richmond Avenue, but more important, it opens up a tract of land containing fine small home sites, wooded and high; Rental prices: About the same as 1938-39 at $30 to $45 for singles.  Demand is good but not exceptional, and there were no vacancies apparent, excepting one HOLC houses about the center of the area; General comments: Street surfaces bad in many parts of the area.  Better values north of the railroad, and the south portion of the area, which is detached, represents the worst portion of all.  A small automobile junk yard is located in this part.  The terrain is low and built up with very old or very small and cheap hosues.  Very slovenly appearance and upkeep.  Poor road surface here expecting for Polion Avenue.  There are a few very small and cheap bungalows along Detroit Avenue in the north part of the area, but these are exceptional in this part.  West of Ramona Boulevard the area is somewhat newer and there are more small brick bungalows and cottages, but the terrain is generally grown up with scrub trees and has not the charm found east of this dividing line.  Also it is more sparsely built up, probably not more than 20 to 25%.  Only one new house was seen in the area, a small frame bungalow near the northwest boundary.  This is one of the areas which stand to benefit greatly by any defense developments along the south shore. Pending at present is decision on a proposed drydock site near the Prince's Bay section.  Institutions have little property here and HOLC the same.  Only three or four "for sale" signs were observed during a tour of the area.

area_description_data.5: Main highway: Henderson Ave. Some of the large old houses were converted to small private schools. Small houses have not suffered so much and due to the location they can still be rented at a fair figure. Sales Prices (Dec.1940): About 5% lower than 1938-39 levels due to lack of demand for the large old fashioned single houses in this area. Today these are difficult to dispose of, even at $7000 to $7500 which is less than half of what they were quoted in pre-depression times immediately prior to 1929. Sales trend is definetely downward, in line with demand, which fades with the demise of the present owners who are principally retired folk. Rental Prices (Dec. 1940): In line with the good rental demand in nearly all sections of Staten Island, this area is no exception. Prices here are fairly firm at same levels as during 1938-39: $55-$65 for larger old houses; $45 to $55 for 6 to 8 room houses. Rental demand is helped by proximity to New York ferries and by the fact that this area is in a five cent fare zone. General Comments:This area is near the U.S. Gypsum Company's plant in New Brighton, which concern has profited indirectly from defense activities in the way of building construction on Staten Island and elsewhere in the New York area. However, no great increase in employment has resulted, and some of those who have been hired come from other boroughs as commuters. The same may be said of shipyard increases. Many of the new employees have been recruited from outside the borough and it is a commonly heard complaint that the Staten Island men "can't even get inside the gates". There are various explanations of this. One is that shipyard work has been at a low ebb here for such a long while that those who were laid off long ago have passed the age where they are regarded as desirables, and are being passed over in favor of younger men from outside. The McWilliams shipyard, within a mile of this area has just been acquired by the National Youth Administration which has announced its intention to use the yard as a training center for those between the ages of 18 and 23 in ship work. About 1400 are to be thus engaged, principally local residents. It is not expected that this will have much effect on the area except insofar as rentable rooms are concerned. area_description_data.5: Principal highways; Victory Blvd., Manor Road.  Good many foreclosures here. (/n) Sales Prices Dec. 1940: Believed slightly lower than 1939-39, possibly due to slight influx of negro population whereas none was in here before.  Prices about $4000 to $5000 for predominant type of single houses in marketable condition.  No demand for 2 family structures.  Few sales and prices are only nominal at $6000 to $6500.  Trend downward.  (/n) Rental prices Dec. 1940: About the same as 1938-39; $35 to $40 for singles and the same goes for units in two family structures,  which generally are supplied with heat.  Trend is stationary. (/n) General comments: There is some movement of Italian population into this area, although not in any considerable numbers as yet.  Negroes have come into the ungraded area just south of C8 and a few have come over into C8.  Sea View Hospital, about a half mile south of the area is a Tuberculosis Sanitarium where some 6000 patients are quartered.  The New York Ctiy administration employs only colored help in this large institution and it is natural that many of these negroes will find their way into adjacent low grade areas, of which this is one of the nearest.  There is no apparent movement of any desirable population toward the area and the trend appears inevitably downward. area_description_data.5: Principal highways; Victory Blvd., Clove Rd.  An early development 1916-18 of cheap type dwellings erected in an area which was greatly improved with park and recreation facilities. (/n) Supplemental Information (/n) Sales Price Dec. 1940: About the same as 1938-39.  This small "pocket" enclosed by parks and a main thoroughfare has no chance for expansion, and being an area of comparatively few foreclosures, has seen little or no activity in recent years.  Excellent recreational facilities, and protection against encroachment afforded by the above mentioned parks has served to steady the area and to head off what would otherwise almost certainly be a strong downward pitch.  Singles nominally priced at $4500 to $5000, with more near the former figure. (/n) Rental prices Dec 1940: Same as 1938-39 and demand is good because of convenient and cheap transportation, and proximity of shopping center and amusements facilities.  $40 to $50 for singles; more are rented at the lower figure. (/n) General comments: No new construction in here and none likely.  Cemetery just across Victory Blvd. from the eastern part of the area.  An example of what outside surroundings can do to "lift" a neighborhood from its normal course.  Without the park and recreational faciltiies at the back door of this neighborhood, it would probably lapse into fourth grade since construction is of cheap quality and population rather low grade.  Trend appears to be static. area_description_data.5: Many foreclosures. One of the oldest communities. Racial picture has changed from German and Irish dominating to Italian dominating. Principal highways: Richmond Rd., Clove. Rd. Supplemental Information: Sales Prices (Dec. 1940): About 5% lower than in 1938-39 for sinlges, which now range principally between $3500 and $5000, with few sales and those chiefly toward the lower end of the bracket. There are a few old frame two family structures in here and these also have suffered a decline amounting to from 5% to 8%. Prices today vary between $3000 and $5500. There is very little demand except at genuinely "bargain" prices which occasionally produce a buyer (Italian) who "takes" in his wife's name. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): Weakening if anything during the past two years. This is still however, a $25 to $35 neighborhood, both for singles and units in two family dwellings. General Comments: HOLC still has 10 houses in the area; 4 have been sold, within the current year. This area is almost entirely surrounded by superior territory. Nevertheless it has little to recommend it and the trend is probably slightly downward, due to old structures, poor appearance and the racial factor. no new construction here recently.

area_description_data.1c: Low grade population. Zoned residential 30%.

area_description_data.5: Principal streets: Victory Blvd., Clove Rd. Due to unfavorable topographical condition, future development likely to be poor. Supplemental Information: Sales Prices (Dec.1940): Arbitrarily set at $3000 to $4500 for singles since there have been no traceable sales in here recently. Two family structures have seen no activity either, and today's prices would probably be a little lower than in 1938-39, following the general trend on Staten Island. From $5000 to $8000 would include most of these. Rental Prices (Dec.1940): About the same as 1938-39, with singles in rentable condition renting from $35 to $40; units in the few available two flats priced the same. General Comments: Sales and rental prices quoted for this area may appear to be a little high considering the grading assigned here. However, the very unfavorable topography, poor appearance of surroundings and yards, wide variety of types and sizes and sparse development all have been considered in grading. This is a typical example of an area where Italians have gone in and built good and even expensive houses right next door to the most wretched hovels, and only a few yards from the swampy bed of a stream. The area has absolutely no charm, regarded as a whole, although there are a number of well constructed and expensive masonry and brick structures, typically the Mediterranean design. Small vegetable gardens are in evidence throughout the area; chickens and pigeons are a common sight, and the prevalence of wrapped-up fig trees indicates unmistakeably the high percentage of Italian dwellers. About the center line of the area, at the north end, is a pumping station, and along the north boundary (Victory Boulevard) are gas stations and auto repair shops. A small auto junk yard is situated about the center of this area. The land is lowest along the center line, north and south, and rises to the east and west. Best values are near the east and west boundaries. Two small new houses, brick bungalows were notes, both at the extreme boundaries of the area (south and west). There is plenty of room for building in here but little likelihood of any but Italians going into the area. Streets are very poor (except boundary streets) and sidewalks lacking. If anything, the trend is downward, and is certainly down as far as it can go to any but Italian buyers.
